      • accepts

        public Optional<MediaType> accepts(List<MediaType> types)
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Check if the given types are acceptable, returning the best match when true, or else Optional.empty. 
         // Accept: text/html
 req.accepts("text/html");
 //  => "text/html"

 // Accept: text/*, application/json
 req.accepts("text/html");
 //  => "text/html"
 req.accepts("text/html");
 //  => "text/html"
 req.accepts("application/json" "text/plain");
 //  => "application/json"
 req.accepts("application/json");
 //  => "application/json"

 // Accept: text/*, application/json
 req.accepts("image/png");
 //  => Optional.empty

 // Accept: text/*;q=.5, application/json
 req.accepts("text/html", "application/json");
 //  => "application/json"
        Specified by:
        accepts in interface  Request
        Parameters:
        types - Types to test for.
        Returns:
        The best acceptable type.

      • accepts

      • params

        public Mutant params()
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Get all the available parameters. A HTTP parameter can be provided in any of these forms:
        • Path parameter, like: /path/:name or /path/{name}
        • Query parameter, like: ?name=jooby
        • Body parameter when Content-Type is application/x-www-form-urlencoded or multipart/form-data
        Specified by:
        params in interface  Request
        Returns:
        All the parameters.

      • param

        public Mutant param(String name)
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Get a HTTP request parameter under the given name. A HTTP parameter can be provided in any of these forms:
        • Path parameter, like: /path/:name or /path/{name}
        • Query parameter, like: ?name=jooby
        • Body parameter when Content-Type is application/x-www-form-urlencoded or multipart/form-data
        The order of precedence is: path, query and body. For example a pattern like: GET /path/:name for /path/jooby?name=rocks produces: 
          assertEquals("jooby", req.param(name).value());

  assertEquals("jooby", req.param(name).toList().get(0));
  assertEquals("rocks", req.param(name).toList().get(1));
        Uploads can be retrieved too when Content-Type is multipart/form-data see Upload for more information.
        Specified by:
        param in interface  Request
        Parameters:
        name - A parameter's name.
        Returns:
        A HTTP request parameter.

      • param

        public Mutant param(String name,
                    String... xss)
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Get a HTTP request parameter under the given name. A HTTP parameter can be provided in any of these forms:
        • Path parameter, like: /path/:name or /path/{name}
        • Query parameter, like: ?name=jooby
        • Body parameter when Content-Type is application/x-www-form-urlencoded or multipart/form-data
        The order of precedence is: path, query and body. For example a pattern like: GET /path/:name for /path/jooby?name=rocks produces: 
          assertEquals("jooby", req.param(name).value());

  assertEquals("jooby", req.param(name).toList().get(0));
  assertEquals("rocks", req.param(name).toList().get(1));
        Uploads can be retrieved too when Content-Type is multipart/form-data see Upload for more information.
        Specified by:
        param in interface  Request
        Parameters:
        name - A parameter's name.
        xss - Xss filter to apply.
        Returns:
        A HTTP request parameter.

      • locale

        public Locale locale()
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Get a locale that best matches the current request or the default locale as specified in application.lang.
        Specified by:
        locale in interface  Request
        Returns:
        A matching locale.

      • locale

        public Locale locale(BiFunction<List<Locale.LanguageRange>,List<Locale>,Locale> filter)
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Get a locale that best matches the current request. The first filter argument is the value of Accept-Language as Locale.LanguageRange and filter while the second argument is a list of supported locales defined by the application.lang property. The next example returns a Locale instance for the best-matching language tag using the lookup mechanism defined in RFC 4647. 
        
 req.locale(Locale::lookup)
        Specified by:
        locale in interface  Request
        Parameters:
        filter - A locale filter.
        Returns:
        A matching locale.

      • locales

        public List<Locale> locales(BiFunction<List<Locale.LanguageRange>,List<Locale>,List<Locale>> filter)
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Get a list of locale that best matches the current request. The first filter argument is the value of Accept-Language as Locale.LanguageRange and filter while the second argument is a list of supported locales defined by the application.lang property. The next example returns a list of matching Locale instances using the filtering mechanism defined in RFC 4647: 
        
 req.locales(Locale::filter)
        Specified by:
        locales in interface  Request
        Parameters:
        filter - A locale filter.
        Returns:
        A list of matching locales.

      • locales

        public List<Locale> locales()
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Get a list of locale that best matches the current request as per Locale.filter(java.util.List<java.util.Locale.LanguageRange>, java.util.Collection<java.util.Locale>, java.util.Locale.FilteringMode).
        Specified by:
        locales in interface  Request
        Returns:
        A list of matching locales or empty list.

      • flash

        public Request.Flash flash()
                    throws NoSuchElementException
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Give you access to flash scope. Usage: 
        
 {
   use(new FlashScope());

   get("/", req -> {
     Map<String, String> flash = req.flash();
     return flash;
   });
 }
        As you can see in the example above, the FlashScope needs to be install it by calling Jooby.use(org.jooby.Jooby.Module) otherwise a call to this method ends in BAD_REQUEST.
        Specified by:
        flash in interface  Request
        Returns:
        A mutable map with attributes from FlashScope.
        Throws:
        NoSuchElementException

      • flash

        public Request flash(String name,
                     Object value)
        Description copied from interface: Request
        Set a flash attribute. Flash scope attributes are accessible from template engines, by prefixing attributes with flash.. For example a call to flash("success", "OK") is accessible from template engines using flash.success
        Specified by:
        flash in interface  Request
        Parameters:
        name - Attribute's name.
        value - Attribute's value.
        Returns:
        This request.
